Check Homogeneity of Variance (Homoscedasticity) - Gold Standard

Source: R/assumptions.R
check_homogeneity_of_variance.Rd

Tests whether groups have equal variances using Levene's test. Required assumption for t-tests and ANOVA. Provides comprehensive interpretation for beginners, including visual diagnostics, variance ratios, and APA 7 formatted results.

This function is designed to be self-explanatory for users new to statistics, with extensive validation and beginner-friendly error messages.

Usage

check_homogeneity_of_variance(
  data,
  groups,
  alpha = 0.05,
  group_names = "groups"
)

Arguments

data

Numeric vector of values to test

groups

Factor or vector indicating group membership. Will be coerced to factor.

alpha

Numeric. Significance level for the test (default 0.05). Must be between 0 and 1.

group_names

Character. Optional name for the grouping variable (for reporting). Default is "groups". Used in all output messages.

Value

An S3 object of class "assumption_check" containing:

  • test: Name of the test ("Levene's Test")

  • assumption: Which assumption was tested ("Homogeneity of Variance")

  • assumption_met: Logical. TRUE if assumption is met (p > alpha)

  • p_value: P-value from Levene's test

  • p_value_formatted: APA 7 formatted p-value (from Level 1)

  • statistic: F-statistic from Levene's test

  • df1: Numerator degrees of freedom

  • df2: Denominator degrees of freedom

  • n_total: Total sample size (after removing NA)

  • n_missing: Number of NA values removed

  • n_groups: Number of groups

  • group_names: Names of the groups

  • variance_ratio: Ratio of largest to smallest group variance

  • group_statistics: Detailed statistics for each group

  • alpha: Significance level used

  • interpretation: One-sentence summary for quick reference

  • recommendation: Actionable next steps

  • publication_text: APA 7 formatted text for manuscripts

  • verbose_explanation: Educational explanation for beginners

  • visual_guide: How to create diagnostic plots

Details

**What is homogeneity of variance?**

This assumption means that all groups being compared should have similar amounts of variability (spread). For example, if comparing customer satisfaction across 3 segments, each segment should have roughly the same standard deviation.

**How to interpret results:** - If p > 0.05: Variances are equal (good news!) - If p < 0.05: Variances differ (use Welch corrections)

**What to do if violated:** 1. Use Welch's t-test (for 2 groups) instead of Student's t-test 2. Use Welch's ANOVA (for 3+ groups) instead of standard ANOVA 3. Consider data transformation if variance ratio > 10

Examples

# Example 1: Equal variances (assumption met)
set.seed(123)
data1 <- c(rnorm(50, mean = 10, sd = 2), rnorm(50, mean = 12, sd = 2))
groups1 <- rep(c("Group A", "Group B"), each = 50)
check_homogeneity_of_variance(data1, groups1)

#> Test Used: Levene's Test 
#> Result: PASS ASSUMPTION MET 
#> p-value: 0.65 
#> 
#> INTERPRETATION:
#>   The homogeneity of variance assumption is MET (Levene's test: F(1, 98) =
#>   0.207, p = .650).
#> 
#> 
#> RECOMMENDATION:
#>   The groups have similar variances. Standard t-test or ANOVA procedures are
#>   appropriate. The variance ratio (largest/smallest) is excellent (ratio = 1.05
#>   < 2).
#> 
#> 
#> PUBLICATION-READY TEXT:
#>   Homogeneity of variance was assessed using Levene's test. The assumption was
#>   met (F(1, 98) = 0.207, p = .650), indicating equal variances across groups.
#>

#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> 
#>   WHAT IS HOMOGENEITY OF VARIANCE?
#>   
#>   Homogeneity of variance (also called homoscedasticity) is a critical
#>   assumption for t-tests and ANOVA. It means that the variability (spread) of
#>   scores should be roughly the same across all groups being compared. Levene's
#>   test evaluates this assumption.
#>   
#>   HOW LEVENE'S TEST WORKS:
#>   
#>   The null hypothesis states that all groups have equal variances. With a
#>   p-value of 0.65 (greater than alpha = 0.05), we fail to reject the null
#>   hypothesis. This is good news! It means the variances across your groups are
#>   statistically similar.
#>   
#>   WHAT THIS MEANS FOR YOUR ANALYSIS:
#>   
#>   The spread of scores is similar across all 2 groups. This means you can use
#>   standard statistical procedures (regular t-test or ANOVA) without
#>   modification. If this assumption had been violated, you would need to use
#>   Welch's t-test or Welch's ANOVA, which don't assume equal variances.
#>   
#>   VARIANCE RATIO INTERPRETATION:
#>   
#>   The variance ratio (largest group variance ÷ smallest) is 1.05. Common
#>   guidelines: • Ratio < 2.0: Excellent equality • Ratio 2.0-3.0: Acceptable •
#>   Ratio 3.0-10.0: Consider Welch correction • Ratio > 10.0: Strongly recommend
#>   Welch correction
#>   
#>   Your ratio is excellent (ratio = 1.05 < 2).
#>   
#>   TECHNICAL DETAILS:
#>   
#>   F-statistic: 0.207 with df = (1, 98) Sample size: 100 across 2 groups
#> 
#> 
#> ========================================================================
#> VISUAL DIAGNOSTICS: How to Check Variance Equality with Plots
#> ========================================================================
#> 
#> Visual inspection often reveals variance differences more clearly than
#> statistical tests. Here's how to create and interpret diagnostic plots:
#> 
#> --- BOXPLOT (Best for Comparing Group Spreads) ---
#> 
#> Create the plot:
#>   boxplot(your_data ~ your_groups,
#>           main = "Distribution by groups",
#>           xlab = "groups",
#>           ylab = "Values",
#>           col = c("lightblue", "lightgreen", "lightyellow"))
#> 
#> How to interpret:
#>   • BOX HEIGHT = Interquartile Range (IQR), reflects spread
#>   • Similar box heights = Similar variances ✓
#>   • Very different box heights = Unequal variances
#>   • Whisker length also indicates spread
#> 
#> Rule of thumb:
#>   - If one box is 2-3x taller than another → Possible violation
#>   - If one box is 5x+ taller than another → Clear violation
#> 
#> --- VARIANCE PLOT (Side-by-Side Standard Deviations) ---
#> 
#> Create the plot:
#>   # Calculate group SDs
#>   group_sds <- tapply(your_data, your_groups, sd)
#>   
#>   # Plot
#>   barplot(group_sds,
#>           main = "Standard Deviation by Group",
#>           xlab = "groups",
#>           ylab = "Standard Deviation",
#>           col = "steelblue")
#>   abline(h = mean(group_sds), col = "red", lty = 2)
#> 
#> How to interpret:
#>   • Bars of similar height = Equal variances ✓
#>   • One bar much taller/shorter = Unequal variances
#>   • Red line shows average SD across groups
#> 
#> --- SPREAD-LOCATION PLOT (Advanced) ---
#> 
#> Create the plot:
#>   # Fit a model
#>   model <- lm(your_data ~ your_groups)
#>   
#>   # Plot residuals vs fitted
#>   plot(model, which = 3)  # Scale-Location plot
#> 
#> How to interpret:
#>   • Horizontal red line = Equal variances ✓
#>   • Upward/downward trend = Variances increase/decrease with mean
#>   • Funnel shape = Heteroscedasticity
#> 
#> --- YOUR GROUP STATISTICS ---
#> 
#>   Group A: SD = 1.85, Var = 3.43, n = 50
#>   Group B: SD = 1.81, Var = 3.28, n = 50
#> 
#> Variance Ratio: 1.05 (Group A.var / Group B.var)
#> 
#> --- PRACTICAL ADVICE ---
#> 
#> • With equal sample sizes: Violations less problematic (tests are 'robust')
#> • With unequal sample sizes: Violations more serious, definitely use Welch
#> • If largest variance goes with smallest n: Most problematic scenario
#> • If largest variance goes with largest n: Less problematic but still use Welch
#> ========================================================================
#> 

# Example 2: Unequal variances (assumption violated)
data2 <- c(rnorm(50, mean = 10, sd = 1), rnorm(50, mean = 12, sd = 5))
groups2 <- rep(c("Low Var", "High Var"), each = 50)
check_homogeneity_of_variance(data2, groups2)

#> 
#> Test Used: Levene's Test 
#> Result: FAIL ASSUMPTION VIOLATED 
#> p-value: 0 
#> 
#> INTERPRETATION:
#>   The homogeneity of variance assumption is VIOLATED (Levene's test: F(1, 98) =
#>   38.921, p < .001).
#> 
#> 
#> RECOMMENDATION:
#>   REQUIRED: Use Welch's t-test (for 2 groups) or Welch's ANOVA (for 3+ groups),
#>   which do not assume equal variances. The variance ratio is 22.14 (severe
#>   violation), indicating meaningful differences in group variability.
#>   
#>   IN R: t.test(formula, data = your_data, var.equal = FALSE) # Welch's t-test
#> 
#> 
#> PUBLICATION-READY TEXT:
#>   Homogeneity of variance was assessed using Levene's test. The assumption was
#>   violated (F(1, 98) = 38.921, p < .001). Accordingly, Welch's correction was
#>   applied.
#>

#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> 
#>   WHAT IS HOMOGENEITY OF VARIANCE?
#>   
#>   Homogeneity of variance (also called homoscedasticity) is a critical
#>   assumption for t-tests and ANOVA. It means that the variability (spread) of
#>   scores should be roughly the same across all groups being compared. Levene's
#>   test evaluates this assumption.
#>   
#>   WHAT THE VIOLATION MEANS:
#>   
#>   The null hypothesis of Levene's test states that all groups have equal
#>   variances. With a p-value of 0 (less than alpha = 0.05), we reject the null
#>   hypothesis. This means the variances across your groups are significantly
#>   different.
#>   
#>   This is a severe violation (variance ratio = 22.14).
#>   
#>   WHY THIS MATTERS:
#>   
#>   When variances are unequal, standard t-tests and ANOVA: • Produce incorrect
#>   standard errors • Give unreliable p-values (often too small) • Can lead to
#>   false positive findings
#>   
#>   This is actually quite common in consumer research, especially when comparing
#>   different market segments or experimental conditions. Don't worry - this
#>   doesn't invalidate your analysis!
#>   
#>   WHAT TO DO (REQUIRED STEPS):
#>   
#>   You MUST use modified versions of your planned tests:
#>   
#>   For 2 groups: Use Welch's t-test R code: t.test(outcome ~ group, data =
#>   your_data, var.equal = FALSE)
#>   
#>   The var.equal = FALSE argument tells R to use Welch's correction.
#>   
#>   These 'Welch' versions do not assume equal variances and will give you valid
#>   results. They're widely accepted in peer-reviewed publications and are often
#>   recommended as the default approach even when variances are equal.
#>   
#>   VARIANCE RATIO INTERPRETATION:
#>   
#>   The variance ratio (largest group variance ÷ smallest) is 22.14.  • Ratio <
#>   3.0: Mild concern, Welch still recommended • Ratio 3.0-10.0: Moderate
#>   concern, MUST use Welch • Ratio > 10.0: Severe concern, MUST use Welch +
#>   consider transformation
#>   
#>   TECHNICAL DETAILS:
#>   
#>   F-statistic: 38.921 with df = (1, 98) Sample size: 100 across 2 groups Group
#>   variances: High Var.var = 21.67, Low Var.var = 0.98
#> 
#> 
#> ========================================================================
#> VISUAL DIAGNOSTICS: How to Check Variance Equality with Plots
#> ========================================================================
#> 
#> Visual inspection often reveals variance differences more clearly than
#> statistical tests. Here's how to create and interpret diagnostic plots:
#> 
#> --- BOXPLOT (Best for Comparing Group Spreads) ---
#> 
#> Create the plot:
#>   boxplot(your_data ~ your_groups,
#>           main = "Distribution by groups",
#>           xlab = "groups",
#>           ylab = "Values",
#>           col = c("lightblue", "lightgreen", "lightyellow"))
#> 
#> How to interpret:
#>   • BOX HEIGHT = Interquartile Range (IQR), reflects spread
#>   • Similar box heights = Similar variances ✓
#>   • Very different box heights = Unequal variances
#>   • Whisker length also indicates spread
#> 
#> Rule of thumb:
#>   - If one box is 2-3x taller than another → Possible violation
#>   - If one box is 5x+ taller than another → Clear violation
#> 
#> --- VARIANCE PLOT (Side-by-Side Standard Deviations) ---
#> 
#> Create the plot:
#>   # Calculate group SDs
#>   group_sds <- tapply(your_data, your_groups, sd)
#>   
#>   # Plot
#>   barplot(group_sds,
#>           main = "Standard Deviation by Group",
#>           xlab = "groups",
#>           ylab = "Standard Deviation",
#>           col = "steelblue")
#>   abline(h = mean(group_sds), col = "red", lty = 2)
#> 
#> How to interpret:
#>   • Bars of similar height = Equal variances ✓
#>   • One bar much taller/shorter = Unequal variances
#>   • Red line shows average SD across groups
#> 
#> --- SPREAD-LOCATION PLOT (Advanced) ---
#> 
#> Create the plot:
#>   # Fit a model
#>   model <- lm(your_data ~ your_groups)
#>   
#>   # Plot residuals vs fitted
#>   plot(model, which = 3)  # Scale-Location plot
#> 
#> How to interpret:
#>   • Horizontal red line = Equal variances ✓
#>   • Upward/downward trend = Variances increase/decrease with mean
#>   • Funnel shape = Heteroscedasticity
#> 
#> --- YOUR GROUP STATISTICS ---
#> 
#>   High Var: SD = 4.65, Var = 21.67, n = 50
#>   Low Var: SD = 0.99, Var = 0.98, n = 50
#> 
#> Variance Ratio: 22.14 (High Var.var / Low Var.var)
#> 
#> --- PRACTICAL ADVICE ---
#> 
#> • With equal sample sizes: Violations less problematic (tests are 'robust')
#> • With unequal sample sizes: Violations more serious, definitely use Welch
#> • If largest variance goes with smallest n: Most problematic scenario
#> • If largest variance goes with largest n: Less problematic but still use Welch
#> ========================================================================
#> 

# Example 3: With missing values
data3 <- c(rnorm(45, 10, 2), rep(NA, 5), rnorm(48, 12, 2), rep(NA, 2))
groups3 <- rep(c("A", "B"), each = 50)
check_homogeneity_of_variance(data3, groups3)
#> Note: 7 missing value(s) removed from test (7% of data)
#>

#> ===
#> ===

#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===

#> ===
#> ===

#> Result: PASS ASSUMPTION MET 
#> p-value: 0.8059 
#> 
#> INTERPRETATION:
#>   The homogeneity of variance assumption is MET (Levene's test: F(1, 91) =

#>   < 2).

#> 
#>   WHAT IS HOMOGENEITY OF VARIANCE?
#>   
#>   Homogeneity of variance (also called homoscedasticity) is a critical
#>   assumption for t-tests and ANOVA. It means that the variability (spread) of
#>   scores should be roughly the same across all groups being compared. Levene's
#>   test evaluates this assumption.
#>   
#>   HOW LEVENE'S TEST WORKS:
#>   
#>   The null hypothesis states that all groups have equal variances. With a
#>   p-value of 0.8059 (greater than alpha = 0.05), we fail to reject the null
#>   hypothesis. This is good news! It means the variances across your groups are
#>   statistically similar.
#>   
#>   WHAT THIS MEANS FOR YOUR ANALYSIS:
#>   
#>   The spread of scores is similar across all 2 groups. This means you can use
#>   standard statistical procedures (regular t-test or ANOVA) without
#>   modification. If this assumption had been violated, you would need to use
#>   Welch's t-test or Welch's ANOVA, which don't assume equal variances.
#>   
#>   VARIANCE RATIO INTERPRETATION:
#>   
#>   The variance ratio (largest group variance ÷ smallest) is 1.01. Common
#>   guidelines: • Ratio < 2.0: Excellent equality • Ratio 2.0-3.0: Acceptable •
#>   Ratio 3.0-10.0: Consider Welch correction • Ratio > 10.0: Strongly recommend
#>   Welch correction
#>   
#>   Your ratio is excellent (ratio = 1.01 < 2).
#>   
#>   TECHNICAL DETAILS:
#>   
#>   F-statistic: 0.061 with df = (1, 91) Sample size: 93 across 2 groups
#> 
#> 
#> ========================================================================
#> VISUAL DIAGNOSTICS: How to Check Variance Equality with Plots
#> ========================================================================
#> 
#> Visual inspection often reveals variance differences more clearly than
#> statistical tests. Here's how to create and interpret diagnostic plots:
#> 
#> --- BOXPLOT (Best for Comparing Group Spreads) ---
#> 
#> Create the plot:
#>   boxplot(your_data ~ your_groups,
#>           main = "Distribution by groups",
#>           xlab = "groups",
#>           ylab = "Values",
#>           col = c("lightblue", "lightgreen", "lightyellow"))
#> 
#> How to interpret:
#>   • BOX HEIGHT = Interquartile Range (IQR), reflects spread
#>   • Similar box heights = Similar variances ✓
#>   • Very different box heights = Unequal variances
#>   • Whisker length also indicates spread
#> 
#> Rule of thumb:
#>   - If one box is 2-3x taller than another → Possible violation
#>   - If one box is 5x+ taller than another → Clear violation
#> 
#> --- VARIANCE PLOT (Side-by-Side Standard Deviations) ---
#> 
#> Create the plot:
#>   # Calculate group SDs
#>   group_sds <- tapply(your_data, your_groups, sd)
#>   
#>   # Plot
#>   barplot(group_sds,
#>           main = "Standard Deviation by Group",
#>           xlab = "groups",
#>           ylab = "Standard Deviation",
#>           col = "steelblue")
#>   abline(h = mean(group_sds), col = "red", lty = 2)
#> 
#> How to interpret:
#>   • Bars of similar height = Equal variances ✓
#>   • One bar much taller/shorter = Unequal variances
#>   • Red line shows average SD across groups
#> 
#> --- SPREAD-LOCATION PLOT (Advanced) ---
#> 
#> Create the plot:
#>   # Fit a model
#>   model <- lm(your_data ~ your_groups)
#>   
#>   # Plot residuals vs fitted
#>   plot(model, which = 3)  # Scale-Location plot
#> 
#> How to interpret:
#>   • Horizontal red line = Equal variances ✓
#>   • Upward/downward trend = Variances increase/decrease with mean
#>   • Funnel shape = Heteroscedasticity
#> 
#> --- YOUR GROUP STATISTICS ---
#> 
#>   A: SD = 1.85, Var = 3.44, n = 45
#>   B: SD = 1.84, Var = 3.39, n = 48
#> 
#> Variance Ratio: 1.01 (A.var / B.var)
#> 
#> --- PRACTICAL ADVICE ---
#> 
#> • With equal sample sizes: Violations less problematic (tests are 'robust')
#> • With unequal sample sizes: Violations more serious, definitely use Welch
#> • If largest variance goes with smallest n: Most problematic scenario
#> • If largest variance goes with largest n: Less problematic but still use Welch
#> ========================================================================
#>
